abstract.text: The DØ collaboration has measured the like-sign dimuon charge asymmetry in pp collisions at the Fermilab Tevatron collider.
The result is significantly different from the standard model expectation of CP violation in mixing.
In this paper we consider the possible causes of this asymmetry and identify one standard model source not considered before.
It decreases the discrepancy of the likesign dimuon charge asymmetry with the standard model prediction, although does not eliminate it completely.

body_text.text: I. INTRODUCTION

The DØ Collaboration has measured [1][2][3][4] the likesign dimuon charge asymmetry and the inclusive muon charge asymmetry in pp collisions at a center-of-mass energy √ s = 1.96 TeV at the Fermilab Tevatron collider.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: After subtracting the known background sources, the inclusive muon charge asymmetry is found to be compatible with zero while the like-sign dimuon charge asymmetry significantly deviates from the standard model (SM) prediction.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This deviation is usually interpreted as the anomalous charge asymmetry of B 0 and B 0 s semileptonic decays [5,6].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In this paper we consider other possible sources of the like-sign dimuon charge asymmetry, taking into account the constraint that the inclusive muon asymmetry is consistent with zero.

body_text.section: IV. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Among all other possible sources of the dimuon charge asymmetry, only the direct CP violation in semileptonic b-and c-hadron decays is not yet limited experimentally.
